value: Big Sur coastline with glimpse of Bixby Bridge, Highway 1

. It contains vast wildernesses and breathtaking views as it stretches 90 miles along the rugged Pacific Ocean. It is approximately 150 miles south of

. The area is great for outdoor recreation and contains several state parks, two national wilderness areas and is part of the Los Padres National Forest, all of which include hiking trails. The most common visitors to Big Sur are those just driving through to enjoy the scenery. The next most common activity is hiking/backpacking in the open natural spaces.

California
(also known as Pacific Coast Highway) winds through Big Sur flanked by the steep Santa Lucia Mountains to the east and the rocky Pacific Coast to the west. Big Sur begins just south of
and continues south through the small towns of Big Sur Village (between Andrew Molera State Park and Pfeiffer Big Sur State Park), Lucia, and Gorda. It ends in

(where the Hearst Castle is located). When driving on Highway 1 through Big Sur be sure to stop at the many turnouts and vista points to see the beauty of the area.

Big Sur Village is a mile-long village containing gas stations, roadside markets, lodges and restaurants.

Big Sur is known as a destination for the "Merry Pranksters" in the 1960s.

For more information visit the Big Sur Chamber of Commerce
, which is continually updated with a Calendar of Events.
Big Sur is a remote area accessible only via

. The easiest and most common way to get there is by car, though some enthusiastic adventurers cycle along the highway. Gas stations are far between and gas is expensive, so best to have plenty of gas when you enter the Big Sur region.
take US-101 south to CA-156 west which merges with
20 miles from the beginning of the Big Sur area. Approximately 125 miles and 2-3 hour drive.
take US-101 north and exit onto
toward Morro Bay/Hearst Castle which is 45 miles south of the end of Big Sur. Approximately 250 miles and 4-5 hour drive.

to Nepenthe in Big Sur. It runs several times a day, seven days a week from Memorial Day to Labor Day (last week of May through first week of September), and weekends only the rest of the year. During winter and spring, the bus is sometimes canceled due to bad weather, so call to check. 888-678-2871,

(see above) stops at several state parks, the Big Sur River Inn, and Nepenthe.

Bicycling along Highway 1 is popular, though challenging.

value: , 11 miles north of Big Sur Village. Iconic bridge built in 1933. One of the most photographed in the world because of its location within such beautiful scenery.
content=Highway 1, a quarter mile south of Nepenthe Restaurant. Wi-Fi internet access.

content=5 miles north of Big Sur Village. Point Sur is a dominant feature along Highway 1. It is a National Historic Landmark and is one of the only complete turn-of-the-century light stations open to the public in California. Allegedly one of the most haunted places in America. Spectacular views can be had from atop Point Sur. Tours (3 hours) are offered - meet west side of highway at farm gate a quarter mile north of Pt Sur Naval Facility. Winter times Sa, Su 10AM, W 1PM. $10 adult, $5 children.

, 12 miles south of Big Sur Village. One of the most spectacular places anywhere in Big Sur. The falls drop 80 feet onto the beach or tide. There is a hike out to a view point but it can also be seen from the road just before Julia Pfeiffer Burns State Park.
, located in Lucia off Highway 1 (25 miles south of Big Sur village), +1 831-667-2456,
. Monastery offering guided retreats, also sells gifts and food items.
Redwoods in Pfeiffer Big Sur State Park

- There are over 80 day hikes, varying in length and difficulty. There are hikes to beaches and vistas along the coast, along rivers and through canyons, and through redwood forests in the Santa Lucia Mts. For longer and more remote adventures, backpacking is an option. There are hundreds of miles of trails through the region, particularly the Ventana Wilderness. Be prepared and know what you are doing before going backpacking in the Wilderness. More information can be found at the Big Sur Ranger Station located 3 miles south of Big Sur Village, +1 831-667-2315. NOTE: Always check conditions before hiking or backpacking. Hiking areas in Big Sur can be closed down in winter due to mudslides. Know before you go.
- Remote and pristine beaches are accessible. Andrew Molera State Park, Pfeiffer Beach, and Sand Dollar Beach are the most commonly visited.

value: content=Less than 1 mile north of Big Sur Village. Miles of trails, beaches, and meadows. Also has 24 primitive camp sites (first come, first serve).
, beaches south of Big Sur Village. Jade is a common semi-precious stone found on the beaches in the Big Sur region.

, 2.5 miles south of Big Sur Village turn west on Sycamore Canyon Rd (unmarked road, only paved and non-gated road to the west in the area). Great sunsets and a fun beach. Dig into the wet sand and find it is purple due to manganese garnet. If you are heading south on Route 1, the key to finding this beach is to look for the yellow sign - "NARROW ROAD No RVs - Trailers"
content=2 miles south of Big Sur Village. There are hiking trails through redwood groves. It is a 1.4 mile round trip to 60-foot Pfeiffer Falls that runs from Dec to May.

content=24 miles north of Big Sur Village (just south of Carmel). Well managed and developed recreation area offering many hikes, beaches, coves and points. Also offers SCUBA by permit only. Often referred to as the crown jewel of the State Park System. $10 per car.
, 35 miles south of Big Sur Village (across Highway 1 from Plaskett Creek Campground, stairs lead to the beach). Largest expanse of sand in Big Sur and also well protected from wind.

, Big Sur Ranger Station (3 miles south of Big Sur Village), 831-667-2315. The wilderness covers 167,323 square acres. Within the wilderness area alone there are 237 miles of trails and 55 designated camping areas.

There are art galleries and gift shops throughout Big Sur all along Highway 1.

value: , fine art by Big Sur artists. A hidden treasure worth finding. Formerly ARS Gallery, located on Hwy 1 at Loma Vista in the Courtyard of the Spirit Garden. Daily except Tu 11:00-6:00. Also by appointment: +1 831-667-2618
content=Located at Loma Vista. Home to Big Sur Arts Initiative non-profit organization. Features a Hidden Garden Tour.
, located at Loma Vista, +1 831-667-2000. Local and exotic gifts and jewelry.
content=Located at Loma Vista. Botanical garden featuring exotic succulents and plants. Also provides cultural, musical, artistic, and educational programs and classes.
content=Rancho Rico. Gallery by appointment only.
content=Located across from Nepenthe. Open daily 10:30AM–6:30PM. Representing works of the Hawthorne family and other internationally known artists.
content=Next to Big Sur River Inn. Shopping featuring jewelry, clothing, and collectibles.
content=Located in Big Sur Village Shops. Local artists and craftsmen featuring Big Sur jade, redwood bowls, and tie-dyed cloths.
content=Open daily 10:30AM–7PM. Natural products featuring tableware, clothing, bedding, and body care products.
content=Personalized artwork, portraits, sculptures and wearable art you can take with you. By appointment.
content=Located by the River Inn upstairs at the Village shops
name=Big Sur Lodge Restaurant & Espresso House
content=Breakfast, lunch, and dinner. On the banks of the Big Sur River, views of redwoods.
content= Breakfast, lunch, and dinner. Deck overlooking Big Sur River. Live entertainment on Sundays.
content=Open for dinner 5:30-9PM. Closed Tuesdays. Call for reservations. Californian-Latin American cuisine.
content=Located on a terrace just below Nepenthe. Open March - December, 9AM-4PM. Brunch and light lunch.
content=Located at Ventana Inn. Open for lunch and dinner seven days a week. Offering 50-mile vistas of the Pacific from the outdoor terrace.
content= Open for lunch and dinner from 11AM-9PM. Excellent Fish & Chips (judged as one of the Top 10 in the US by Coastal Living Magazine).
, next to Big Sur River Inn in the Village Center Shops, +1 831-667-2355. Classic affordable pub with food and drinks.
content=Highway 1. Picturesque dining location overlooking 40 miles of coastline.
content=Located 15 miles north of Hearst Castle.
content=Located at Fernwood Resort. Open 11AM-9PM. Serves buffalo burgers, salmon burgers, hamburgers, veggie burgers, sandwiches, salads and more.
content=Open 8AM-2PM. American cuisine with Spanish flair. $5–12 per entree.
content=Panoramic ocean view. Pool table, TV's, live entertainment. Wi-Fi internet Access.
content=Located at the Post Ranch Inn. Light lunch noon - 3:30, drinks 3:30 to close, dinner nightly. At 1,149 feet the restaurant offers great views of the coastline.

Many local restaurants also contain bars and/or provide drinks.

value: content=Just north of Big Sur Village. Cabins, tents, RV's, all allowed but with limited availability. Also has a bar and grill as well as other resort amenities.
, next to Big Sur River Inn in the Village Center Shops, 831-667-2355. Classic affordable pub with food and drinks.

The two main options for sleeping in Big Sur are either camping or staying in a hotel/resort. Some locations have both options provided. Camping is popular in Big Sur and there are many small campgrounds through the region that are not listed below but can be found along Highway 1.

value: content= Accommodations include campsites, tent-cabins and rustic cabins, all beneath giant redwoods and beside the Big Sur river. There is great swimming in the river and hiking is close by. Kids can ride inner-tubes or rubber boats down the river and a short 3 mile drive either north or south will get you to beautiful beaches (Pfieffer to the south and Molera to the north.)
, 47225 Highway 1, Big Sur (just south of Big Sur Village), +1-800-424-4787 or +1 831-667-3100,
. Lies within Pfeiffer Big Sur State Park. Contains 61 cottage style units and all resort amenities.

content= Heated swimming pool. Full service restaurant and bar. 20 guest rooms. Rates: Rooms with one queen bed $125–170; Rooms with two queen sized beds $150–215; Two room, Riverside Suite with one king size bed and two single day beds $225–270. The higher rates are in effect during high season. The rooms are in cabins made from fragrant wood, the beds are comfortable, and there are excellent products for the shower, so you do get value for your money.
content= Norwegian-style setting nestled in the redwoods of Castro Canyon. (Advanced reservations recommended)
content=Just north of Big Sur Village. Cabins, tents, RV's, all allowed but with limited availability. Also has a bar and grill as well as other resort amenities.
content=Highway 1, Big Sur.  17 clean and comfortable units available year-round.

content=Highway 1. Gorgeous campsites along a creek that runs into the ocean. Sites on the beach and under the redwoods. There are a few small hikes to the historic limekilns and a significant waterfall (be prepared to cross the creek a few times to get to the waterfall, but it's so worth it in the spring).
content= Coastal cabins with great views of the coastline ranging in price and privacy.
, Highway 1 (2 miles south of Big Sur Village), 888-524-4787 or 831-667-2200,
. High end resort style accommodations, three pools, spas, and private decks. Sits 1200 feet above the Pacific.
content=20 miles north of San Simieon on Highway 1. 30 rooms and a gourmet restaurant. Nearby stores, snacks and espresso.
content= Features 16 yurts and 5 campsites. Amenities include pool, hot tub, restaurant, gift shop, and lodge.
content=28 miles south of Carmel. Ultra-luxurious resort with all possible amentias including pools, hot tubs, sauna, restaurant, bar, and of course great views.

. Just south of Lucia and Limekiln SP. All campsites are located on a bluff overlooking the Pacific. There are few trees (much warmer than under the redwoods!) and the sites are on well kept grass. Amazing sunsets and decent bathrooms. There are a few nice short trails leading down to the beach.

Be aware that there are long stretches of coastline with little or no cell phone signal, and plan accordingly. Also, fill your gas tank before you drive to the area, as gas stations are few, and some charge as much as $7 a gallon! It is also highly advisable to buy bottled water or replenish your supply from good tap water (the tap water in Big Sur Village, for example, which is delicious mountain spring water) when you have the chance, and try to avoid being caught having to drive long distances after dark with the fog rolling over the highway. Big Sur is very wild country for long stretches. A sign that might exemplify this for you is one that appears on Route 1 southbound, showing curves, with the text "Next 72 miles"!

Always check traffic conditions as the highway is a single lane on each side and land slides can cause major hold ups with construction reducing the roadway to a single lane, controlled by a light. Southbound wait during these periods at peak conditions can extend to several hours.
